entry.title: Why does Spotify want me to listen to Sabrina Carpenter so bad?

entry.content:
Steven Phillips-Horst had a problem â€” er, â€œproblem,â€ depending on who you ask â€” that plagues many a modern Spotify listener. No matter what song the podcaster and comedian played, whether by Taylor Swift or Celine Dion, Morgan Wallen or the band How to Dress Well, the platform would immediately queue up Sabrina Carpenterâ€™s â€œEspressoâ€ next.

â€œHow is it that no matter what direction my unique personality takes me in, it leads me back to this same song that I only heard three days ago that I donâ€™t even really like that much?â€ he asks over the phone, not knowing that the same thing had been happening to me, too. 

The disco-inflected soft pop hit, performed by a Polly Pocket-sized former Disney Channel star, was deemed the song of summer nearly as soon as it was released in mid-April. But Phillips-Horst wondered, was that because the song was good? Or, as he proposed on X, was it because of the tantalizing (if unfounded) theory that Carpenterâ€™s label was paying Spotify to force-feed â€œEspressoâ€ down the throats of listeners the world over?

â€œItâ€™s not an â€˜algorithm,â€™â€ he wrote. â€œThe label is paying for radio play in an old school, industry plant kinda way and itâ€™s honestly refreshing. We are so back etc!â€ Responses flooded in, with hundreds of others saying they too couldnâ€™t escape â€œEspressoâ€ or other hits from new-ish entries into the pop game, namely Chappell Roanâ€™s â€œGood Luck, Babe!â€ and Tommy Richmanâ€™s â€œMillion Dollar Baby.â€ 

The theory seems to be an increasingly popular one: that the biggest music streaming platform in the world has arrangements with record labels to boost streams for particular songs and artists. Itâ€™s not exactly a far-fetched conclusion. The history of pop music is rife with payola scandals, in which powerful executives (and sometimes the literal mafia) manufactured hits by paying for radio play, and, after the practice was first outlawed in 1960, finding loopholes to get around each new restriction. â€œWhen publicity is valuable, people will inevitably find ways to pay for it,â€ says Gabriel Rossman, a sociologist at UCLA who studies bribery in the music industry.Â 

Thereâ€™s no hard evidence to suggest that labels are directly paying Spotify to boost certain artists and songs, according to the music industry scholars and insiders I interviewed. Yet itâ€™s almost impossible to prove that itâ€™s not happening: Deals between record labels and streaming platforms are confidential and algorithms are intentionally designed as black boxes. (Spotify would not agree to an interview, but said in a statement that â€œThe remarkable growth of fan bases for artists like Sabrina Carpenter, Chappell Roan, and Tommy Richman on Spotify is a testament to their hard work and artistry.â€)

While the most likely explanation is the most boring â€” that certain songs take off on music discovery algorithms because listeners seem to like them â€” the question of why users keep getting served Sabrina Carpenter is far more complex than that. No wonder so many of us think something shady is going on, even if we canâ€™t quite put our fingers on what.

How Spotifyâ€™s algorithm works

Users tend to refer to a singular, all-powerful Spotify algorithm, but there is no single one that determines what songs are served to its 600 million listeners. Rather each of the platformâ€™s features work differently and have specific (albeit similar) goals. â€œSmart Shuffle,â€ for example, queues new songs to a playlist youâ€™ve already made, while the personalized â€œDiscover Weeklyâ€ uses an algorithm meant to design a playlist of new songs that are similar to the music youâ€™ve recently listened to. Newer features like daylists and the AI-powered DJ X are also based on usersâ€™ â€œtaste profiles.â€ Search for a specific song and Spotify will typically autoplay music thatâ€™s sonically similar to the one you searched for, while Spotify Radio creates personalized playlists out of any song, album, or artist you choose.Â 

Many of these features are the subject of mistrust and theorizing among the listening public. The website PopFiltr found that Carpenterâ€™s new single â€œPlease Please Pleaseâ€ took the No. 2 spot on dozens of artistsâ€™ Radio playlists. This would make sense for modern pop acts like Harry Styles or Lana Del Rey but less so for, say, Frank Sinatra, Creedence Clearwater Revival, or one playlist based on the artist â€œFart Fest,â€ which publishes literal fart noises. (I wasnâ€™t able to recreate these findings, as theyâ€™re algorithmically tailored to each user, but â€œPlease Please Pleaseâ€ was second in Radio playlists for Clairo, Boygenius, Charli XCX, and Dua Lipa, and was almost always followed by a Chappell Roan song and â€œEspresso.â€)Â 

Youâ€™d think all this means that somewhere in the depths of Spotifyâ€™s servers, thereâ€™s a giant lever that pushes Carpenterâ€™s music out to millions of people at once. But, as Glenn McDonald, the former â€œdata alchemistâ€ at Spotify and founder of the music microgenre catalog Every Noise at Once, explains, â€œNone of it is as centralized as youâ€™re imagining â€” itâ€™s not like thereâ€™s a master sticker on the song that causes everybody to promote it.â€

McDonald, who understands how Spotify works better than perhaps anyone, says that the question shouldnâ€™t be about payola or some other seedy arrangement between Spotify and music labels, but about algorithms: â€œA lot of things on Spotify are trying to keep you in your comfort zone and play you the right things.â€ 

Noah Askin, a computational social scientist who studies the music industry, says that algorithms like Spotifyâ€™s typically use collaborative filtering, a concept used by recommendation engines to predict what users want to be served next. The gist is that if User A and User B have overlapping tastes, User A will probably enjoy the other music that User B is listening to. 

He also points to the Matthew Effect, or the idea that the already successful will have an easier time becoming more successful. Music recommendation algorithms can make big songs even bigger at the expense of others. â€œOnce you have a bunch of attention, itâ€™s much easier to get more attention,â€ Askin says. â€œWhen a BeyoncÃ© song comes out, itâ€™s more likely to get played because sheâ€™s already more popular â€¦ and so the people who donâ€™t listen to her but are into pop music, guess who theyâ€™re going to get fed?â€Â 

He compares this to the Google and Netflix algorithms, which take an impossibly large slew of content and present it to users in a way that will make them spend as much time as possible on their platforms. The platforms do this by pushing out whatâ€™s already proven catchy with people with similar tastes.Â 

Neither Roan nor Carpenter is anywhere near as famous as BeyoncÃ©, but Askin suspects part of the reason they keep showing up on pop fansâ€™ Spotify algorithms is due to a sociological concept called â€œoptimal distinctivenessâ€ that explains many listenersâ€™ tastes. â€œWhat we found was that the songs that are pretty similar to what’s popular but a little bit distinctive are the ones that do best,â€ he says. â€œIf it all just sounds the same, it gets boring. On the other end of the spectrum, anything thatâ€™s too weird, itâ€™s like … Iâ€™m not interested in really pushing my listening horizons that much.â€

One 2009 study on optimal distinctiveness found that young people preferred and identified more with music styles at â€œintermediateâ€ popularity levels, as opposed to either massively popular or esoteric ones. Spotifyâ€™s algorithms likely reflect and strengthen that bias, to its own benefit. â€œWhat Spotify cares about [is that] you continue to listen on their platform, that you stay on their platform for as long as possible. And whatâ€™s going to do that is providing people with songs that sound like what they like but have some degree of novelty to them,â€ says Askin.

McDonaldâ€™s assessment of the Spotify algorithm echoes Askinâ€™s: â€œEspecially if [the artist] is slightly less popular and a bit more attuned to what you usually like, then that makes them a better match than someone whoâ€™s very popular and crosses genre or audience boundaries.â€ A Taylor Swift listener, then, would be more likely to get fed â€œEspressoâ€ or â€œGood Luck, Babe!â€ than a Carpenter or Roan listener would get served Swift.Â 

There are also less tangible reasons why certain songs appear to be overnight successes when theyâ€™re anything but. â€œEspressoâ€ may sound like a lot of disco-inspired pop these days, but Carpenterâ€™s opening stint on Taylor Swiftâ€™s Eras Tour, her buzzy romance with actor Barry Keoghan, and a fun persona as â€œa proudly flippant ditz who is so much savvier than she seems,â€ as my colleague described it, all undoubtedly played a part in making the song the sensation it became. 

Chappell Roan, meanwhile, has been publicly trying to â€œmake itâ€ in music for years; she was dropped by her label after her 2020 single flopped â€” a single that just entered the Billboard Hot 100 for the first time. After scoring a spot on Olivia Rodrigoâ€™s tour earlier this year and an NPR Tiny Desk concert, more fans were exposed to her high-energy, drag-inspired stage performances, drawing enormous crowds at music festivals this spring. Despite the accusations Roan and Carpenter have faced of being â€œindustry plantsâ€ (allegations often marred in sexism), there are clearly other explanations for their recent success beyond literally paying Spotify for it.

Even if itâ€™s â€œpayola,â€ itâ€™s not payola

If record labels were paying Spotify for streams, it still wouldnâ€™t technically be payola. US laws against payola, or the practice of paying a radio station to play a specific song without disclosing the payment, only apply to public airwaves. Because there is a finite amount of bandwidth for radio, they have to be managed in the public interest, Rossman explains. â€œThe [Federal Communications Commission] gets to tell broadcasters as a condition of their license that they have to follow certain rules.â€

The internet, on the other hand, is capable of disseminating virtually limitless data, and therefore the payola laws donâ€™t apply. In theory, anyone can build a Spotify competitor and queue up whatever songs they desire (fun dinner party question: youâ€™re the CEO of Spotify, whatâ€™s your â€œEspressoâ€?).Â 

Spotify actually does offer a version of pay-for-play thatâ€™s theoretically available to any artist who opts in. In 2020, it debuted a feature that allowed recording artists to forfeit 30 percent of streaming profits in order to increase the likelihood that a song will be played during a listening session. The program, called Discovery Mode, was immediately likened to payola by the Recording Academy when it launched. 

While music managers said they loved the program â€” some said it increased a songâ€™s streams by 200 to 300 percent â€” three members of Congress slammed Discovery Mode for penalizing up-and-coming artists in an effort to beef up Spotify’s bottom line, according to a letter obtained by Variety. The program â€œmay set in motion a â€˜race to the bottomâ€™ in which artists and labels feel compelled to accept lower royalties as a necessary way to break through an extremely crowded and competitive music environment,â€ they wrote to Spotify co-founder and CEO Daniel Ek.

The artists using Discovery Mode are likely not the Sabrina Carpenters of the world. In its marketing materials, Spotify highlights the success stories of a handful of smaller acts signed to independent record labels who have used the service. But because of the stigma associated with pay-for-play, itâ€™s understandable that few would be transparent about it. Itâ€™s impossible to say for sure how many or which artists use Discovery Mode, however, because Spotify doesnâ€™t label its songs as such.

Major label artists may not need to use Discovery Mode in part because two of the three biggest labels in the world, Universal and Sony, own between 6 and 7 percent of Spotify stock, according to one 2020 estimate. â€œSpotify is reliant on the major labels in particular for access to the catalogs of music that are driving its growth. It needs to play to their tune,â€ one music business scholar told NME. The major labels â€œhave these tier one relationships with people that work at Spotify â€¦ and opportunities can come from that.â€ explains George Goodrich, founder and CEO of Playlist Push, an agency that allows artists to pay for consideration on top Spotify playlists and in influencersâ€™ TikTok videos. â€œItâ€™s all just about connections.â€

Indeed, â€œplaylistingâ€ has been another important strategy for marketers since the 2010s. Artists and their teams enlist agencies toÂ submit songs to independent playlist curators ($285 for consideration in 48 playlists, $3,000 for 500), who can either choose to include them or not; services like Playlist Push are clear in noting that paying for editorial consideration is no guarantee that a song will end up in a popular playlist.Â Playlist Push says they have worked with more than 25,000 artists, labels, and managers since 2017. A prime spot in a big playlist can launch an artistâ€™s career: One record exec compared the Spotify editorial playlist RapCaviar to â€œHot 97 in the early â€™90s,â€ helping to blow up songs like Cardi Bâ€™s 2017 breakout â€œBodak Yellowâ€ and Lil Uzi Vertâ€™s â€œXO TOUR Llif3.â€

One illicit way music marketers have paid for artificial boosts: stream farming. In 2021, Rolling Stone investigated the pay-for-play â€œblack marketâ€ where third-party companies promise to net hundreds of millions of streams per month, typically via bot accounts, for a certain network of artists. â€œThere are a few third-party companies out there running this for a lot of the major companies,â€ one anonymous record label employee told the magazine. â€œWe use them too for some of our artists.â€ Itâ€™s risky business, though. Spotify penalizes artists whose songs have been found to be targets of artificial streams, even in cases where the artist or label wasnâ€™t involved in the scheme. â€œItâ€™s really terrible for your data profile on Spotify,â€ says Goodrich.Â 

Without resorting to stream-farming or some other hidden algorithmic boost, music marketers have gotten far savvier at predicting what will hit with listeners. What seems like sudden ubiquity for a song or artist is often extremely canny strategizing by well-connected industry insiders who are adept at responding to online chatter and listening habits. â€œPeople will tease songs for weeks, if not months, where the audio is already on short-form platforms but not commercially available on streaming services yet. People also test singles that way to see if their feelings on songs are right,â€ says Jenny Kaufman, the head of global streaming promotion at Crush Music. Post Malone and Morgan Wallen teased their song â€œI Had Some Helpâ€ on social media for months before it was released in May; it was recently the No. 1 song on the Billboard charts (though now second to â€œPlease Please Please.â€) â€œWeâ€™re seeing more and more artists drop full albums, weâ€™re seeing more and more artists do less lead-in singles. That in part is due to the interest in seeing which songs fans will react to.â€

On TikTok, which wields enormous influence on the music industry, labels will often partner with talent agencies to pay influencers to use their music in videos. Goodrich points to the success of â€œMillion Dollar Baby,â€ which Richman teased on TikTok in April and which blew up on the platform immediately. He guesses it capitalized on the savviness and connections of manager Ty Baisden, and artist and agency founder Brent Faiyaz. â€œUsually, these songs will have an entire team behind it thatâ€™s literally social engineering the whole thing,â€ says Goodrich. â€œThey have extremely creative people who are thinking about how they can make the song take off, and theyâ€™re usually pretty good at it. And theyâ€™ve figured out some type of formula that no one else has.â€

Why people are inclined to believe a Spotify conspiracy theory 

Considering all the unseen, mysterious ways that algorithms function and music marketers do their work, itâ€™s almost easier to think that everything weâ€™re hearing on streaming platforms amounts to straightforward payola. Perhaps itâ€™s not a coincidence that Phillips-Horstâ€™s tweet expresses a bit of ironic nostalgia for the days when payola was a reasonable explanation for a songâ€™s popularity.

True, other kinds of pay-for-play transactions could very well be happening â€” again, those contracts are confidential, and none of the record labels I reached out to responded to my request for comment â€” but it wouldnâ€™t fall under the FCCâ€™s payola law. Though experts on algorithms disagree, Rossman says he could still envision labels paying the platform to promote certain songs. â€œIt seems plausible,â€ Rossman says. â€œAnd I would expect it to happen.â€ 

Rossman suggests that such agreements should fall under the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s laws that require influencers to disclose advertisements. If Spotify â€œwanted to be safe, all theyâ€™d have to do is include something in the metatext saying, â€˜This artist opted into the Discovery Mode program,â€™â€ he says. â€œOr, â€˜You got this certain song because it has these attributes and we provide this weight to those attributes.â€™ Theyâ€™re doing that internally somewhere on the Spotify servers, theyâ€™re just not sending it to the user.â€ (An FTC spokesperson told me it does not comment on specific companies unless it has publicly announced an action against them.)

The only reason weâ€™re having this conversation at all is because Spotify and other streaming platforms intentionally obscure how they work. â€œAs a listener, I wish I could tell on any given song, â€˜Why is this here? Why should I trust you?â€™â€ says McDonald. But crucially, he says, â€œTo me, this is not a Spotify-specific problem, not a music-specific problem. Itâ€™s everything about how technology mediates human interaction, if it goes through these black boxes of machine learning or AI. Youâ€™re just left [asking] â€˜Here’s the answer, how do I trust it?â€™ â€¦ I think that’s a bad state, that we as people who work on technology have to improve.â€

In 2023, Spotify laid off around 2,200 workers, including McDonald. Its efforts of late have centered around launching new AI features, including one in which users can prompt an AI tool to create a playlist based on a few words. Pricing for the service rose again this June, with individual plans going up $1 per month, up to $11.99. The result will no doubt be more anxiety and confusion among its listeners, who will continue to wonder why its algorithms have so much power over the soundtrack to their lives, or whether itâ€™s even an algorithm at all. 

â€œPeople should demand transparency and control over their own experience,â€ McDonald adds. â€œAlgorithms are tools, but many times these tools are only operated by the people who run the streaming platform, the search engine, or the shopping site. To the extent that those tools can be given to you, the person, to empower yourself and to amplify your curiosity … thatâ€™s more interesting to me than things that just ask you, â€˜Hold still, and weâ€™ll discover something for you.â€™â€

For now, the summer of Spotify conspiracy theories rages on, while the internet debates which artists are industry plants and which labels are doing payola, even if â€” and in fact, because â€” we canâ€™t quite grasp who or how. â€œAnd the grammy for the best autoplay song of the year goes to,â€ wrote one person on X, â€œour payola queen Sabrina Carpenter.â€

entry.title: Democrats say Trump is an existential threat. Theyâ€™re not acting like it.
entry.summary: For a fractious coalition that at times seems to be held together with spit, baling wire, and old memories of Barack Obama, the Democratic Party has a remarkably singular message: Donald Trump is an existential threat to the country. For the Biden campaign, the existential threat to democracy has become the overriding theme in his […]
entry.content:
For a fractious coalition that at times seems to be held together with spit, baling wire, and old memories of Barack Obama, the Democratic Party has a remarkably singular message: Donald Trump is an existential threat to the country.

For the Biden campaign, the existential threat to democracy has become the overriding theme in his bid for reelection. â€œThere is one existential threat: Itâ€™s Donald Trump,â€ Biden said at a fundraiser in February.

For the environmental activists in the party, climate change is the existential concern, and a Trump victory would be devastating for the planet, as Biden himself argued at Thursdayâ€™s debate: â€œThe only existential threat to humanity is climate change, and [Trump] didnâ€™t do a damn thing about it.â€Â 

Reproductive rights, too, are cast in existential terms. â€œTrump poses an existential threat to abortion rights in Pennsylvania,â€ Democratic US Rep. Mary Gay Scanlon said at a press conference in April. â€œIf given the chance, he will ban abortion across the country with or without Congress.â€

Existential math

As it happens, I know a little bit about existential threats, having written a book in 2019 on the subject. It refers to those threats that could conceivably risk the extinction or widespread destruction of humanity.

The real way to tell the difference between an existential threat and a more ordinary one is not what people warning say, itâ€™s what they do. Existential threats demand existential responses. After all, if you conceivably felt the country and perhaps even the world were truly at risk, youâ€™d presumably do everything you could to prevent that catastrophe.Â 

When it comes to the Democrats and the left â€” from the Biden campaign on down to the activists â€” it is impossible to look at what theyâ€™re doing and conclude that they truly believe Donald Trump is an existential threat. And that may pose an existential challenge to the party.

Winning is the only thing

Biden entered Thursday nightâ€™s debate clearly losing, and itâ€™s safe to say that afterward, very few people â€” outside perhaps Bidenâ€™s inner circle â€” think the president is positioned to win this election. The debate spotlighted the one issue that voters have repeatedly told pollsters is a serious problem, the one issue Biden can do almost nothing to change: his age. And rather than seizing a rare opportunity to disprove those fears, Bidenâ€™s halting, often disoriented performance did the opposite.Â 

Cue the Democratic panic and an entire New York Times editorial board worth of columnists urging Biden to step aside. The campaign instantly said, as it has said every time these calls have been made, that the president would do no such thing, and at this point thereâ€™s little reason not to believe them.

Some of this is risk aversion: A president has never called off a reelection bid this late in the campaign, and no one really knows what would come next. Some of it is presumably pride. Biden is a proud man who was on his third try for the presidency when he finally won in 2020. Giving up is not really in his DNA.Â 

Some of it is political calculation. If the president steps aside, the logical candidate is Vice-President Kamala Harris, but Harris has struggled in office and her poor poll ratings mirror those of Biden. If the Democratic Party tries to sideline Harris and open the door to other candidates through an open convention, they risk alienating her and her supporters and opening up further wounds in the Democratic coalition.Â 

Bad choices, all. But the nature of an existential threat is that everything else â€” feelings, ambition, everything â€” is put aside. Yet even as the chance of a second Trump presidency rises by the day, the Democratic political establishment does nothing. Thatâ€™s not how you act in the face of an existential threat. 

Existential until it isnâ€™t

Itâ€™s not just politicians, though. The winners of presidential elections pick Supreme Court justices, and it was obvious that a then-83-year-old Ruth Bader Ginsburg might not make it through the next presidential term after the 2016 election, potentially imperiling abortion rights, among other Democratic priorities. Yet Ginsburg â€” buoyed by a number of Democratic supporters who viewed calls for her retirement as sexist â€” refused to step down. We all know what happened later.Â 

One would think that sitting Democratic justices would have learned from Ginsburgâ€™s example and acted differently in the face of a new supposedly existential threat from Trump. Yet Justices Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan â€” who are 70 and 64, respectively â€” have so far refused to heed increasingly desperate calls from writers like my colleague Ian Milhiser to step down and lock in their seats for decades. Each has perfectly good reasons to stay on, as did Ginsburg; none of those reasons make sense in the face of a true existential threat.

Nowhere is the gap between existential rhetoric and existential action greater than in climate change, which has emerged in recent years as one of the top priorities for Democrats.Â 

You canâ€™t find a climate activist â€” and, increasingly, a Democratic politician â€” who doesnâ€™t frame climate change as an existential issue. With reason â€” the worst-case climate scenarios really do represent something like an existential threat to the future of not just the US, but the entire world. And given Trumpâ€™s determined opposition to actual climate policy, itâ€™s fair to view his potential return to the White House as a part of that threat.Â 

Yet there is a clear and yawning gap between climate rhetoric and climate action. On the Democratic political side, thatâ€™s perhaps understandable; climate change is not a top priority for most voters, and politicians have to grapple with that fact. (You canâ€™t save the Earth if you donâ€™t have the votes.)Â 

Too often, though, climate activists and groups end up opposing many of the new energy projects that are needed to actually decarbonize energy, from transmission lines to solar projects to wind power, often tying them up in years of litigation. The Sunrise Movement, one of the most radical climate activist groups out there, has bafflingly withheld its endorsement from Biden so far, even though he prioritized passage of the most ambitious climate bill in US history.Â 

The groups have reasons for what theyâ€™re doing â€” there are always reasons â€” but if climate change were treated as the existential threat the loudest activists say it is, those reasons wouldnâ€™t matter.

Do you believe what you say?

Treating an existential threat as existential requires the one thing that the Democratic coalition has increasingly struggled to do: prioritization. It means putting aside personal feelings, individual ambition, and subjective preferences in favor of a single goal: success. Otherwise, itâ€™s just empty rhetoric.

As New York Times columnist Ezra Klein, who has been pushing the possibility of an open convention to replace Biden, said on his podcast after Thursdayâ€™s debate: â€œIf the fate of American democracy is hinging on this election â€” as Democrats are always telling me it is and as I think there is a chance that it is â€” then you should do everything you can to win it.â€ That a strategy, any strategy, might make people or groups uncomfortable cannot be a reason not to pursue it in the face of an existential threat. Not if you believe what youâ€™re saying.Â Â Â 

This story originally appeared in Today, Explained, Voxâ€™s flagship daily newsletter. Sign up here for future editions.

entry.title: How dangerous is it really to have a baby in America?
entry.summary: What is â€œmaternal mortalityâ€? The dry, clinical term obscures a devastating loss: A person dies as a result of bringing a child into the world. That child loses a parent; a household is plunged into grief; a family that should be celebrating is left to mourn. Pretty much everyone can agree that such deaths are […]
entry.content:
What is â€œmaternal mortalityâ€?

The dry, clinical term obscures a devastating loss: A person dies as a result of bringing a child into the world. That child loses a parent; a household is plunged into grief; a family that should be celebrating is left to mourn. Pretty much everyone can agree that such deaths are tragic and that even one is too many. What experts donâ€™t agree on is how to count them.

For years, researchers have been warning the public that maternal deaths in America were rising, more than doubling between the 2000s and 2010s, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).Â 

That spike, shocking for one of the wealthiest countries in the world, drew concern from health professionals and policymakers alike, with many states and the federal government establishing task forces to make birth safer. Last year, for example, the Department of Health and Human Services announced $90 million in awards to fight maternal mortality.

Now, some scholars are arguing that the CDCâ€™s methods have become too broad in recent years and capture deaths that arenâ€™t related to pregnancy. Others, meanwhile, say the CDC numbers remain the best way to capture a complicated picture, in which underlying conditions can combine with poor prenatal and postpartum care to cause preventable illness and death.Â 

This debate is about more than just numbers. It has thrown into question two decades of policies and practices around childbirth and its risks.

Is the maternal mortality crisis referenced repeatedly in American media outlets (including Vox) overblown? And if so, are the initiatives meant to fix the problem â€” and the many other efforts experts and advocacy groups have long recommended â€” still necessary?Â 

Answering these questions will determine how we think and talk about pregnancy and childbirth, and how the US cares for people at an incredibly vulnerable time in their lives. 

What the CDC says about maternal deaths

Maternal deaths in the US are counted in a few different ways, including analysis by state and local committees. But the topline national numbers that get the most attention come from the CDCâ€™s National Center for Health Statistics. According to the agency, maternal mortality is a serious problem in America, one thatâ€™s only grown over the past two decades.

In 2022, the most recent year for which data are available, the agency reported that 817 women died during or soon after pregnancy from causes â€œrelated to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management.â€ Maternal mortality is often expressed as a ratio of maternal deaths to live births: For 2022, that ratio was 22.3 deaths per 100,000 births. That was less than in 2021, when the rate was 32.9 per 100,000, but still a marked increase from 2003, when the rate was 12.1 per 100,000.

Itâ€™s also much higher than rates around the world. A recent study by the Commonwealth Fund, a foundation focused on health care access, found the US had the highest maternal mortality rate of any wealthy country. For comparison, Canada had 8.4 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in 2022, Japan had 3.4, and Switzerland had just 1.2.

The CDC has also found severe inequities within the US â€” in 2022, the mortality rate for Black women was 49.5 deaths per 100,000 births, more than twice the rate for white women â€” and the agency reports that more than 80 percent of pregnancy-related deaths in the US are preventable, based on analysis by teams of OB-GYNs, midwives, and other experts.

The criticisms of the CDCâ€™s measurement stem from a change in the way the agency counts maternal deaths. Until the 1990s, countries typically counted a death as maternal if pregnancy or a related condition was listed as the â€œunderlying cause of deathâ€ on a death certificate, according to an analysis published in May by Saloni Dattani at Our World in Data. 

But this approach missed many deaths in which pregnancy or childbirth exacerbated an underlying condition, like AIDS or cardiovascular disease. Officials with the International Classification of Diseases (ICD), a system used around the world for classifying death and illness, came to the conclusion that maternal deaths were being undercounted, and in 1994, they recommended that countries add a â€œpregnancy checkboxâ€ to death certificates to signify whether the deceased had been pregnant or had recently given birth. This would help analysts determine if pregnancy contributed to a death.

US states began adding the checkbox to their death certificates in 2003; by 2017, all had done so. Over this period, nationwide maternal mortality also rose significantly, from 12.1 deaths per 100,000 in 2003 to 17.4 per 100,000 in 2018.

Now, some experts are taking a closer look at the checkbox and the effect it has had on how we understand childbirth in America. They have two separate but related criticisms. Letâ€™s break them down.

Some critics argue that the maternal mortality rate isnâ€™t really rising

Dattani, a researcher who specializes in global health, writes that in order to prevent maternal deaths, â€œitâ€™s crucial to have accurate data.â€ To that end, her May analysis at Our World in Data explains research first conducted by the CDCâ€™s National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) in 2020, adding background and context.Â 

Dattani concludes that the increase in maternal deaths between 2003 and 2017 â€” the period when states were adding the pregnancy checkbox to their death certificates â€” can be attributed largely, or maybe even entirely, to the addition of the box. That is, pregnancy didnâ€™t get more dangerous during that time period, officials just got better at measuring the deaths connected to it.

This conclusion is a big deal because a lot of recent coverage of maternal mortality has been based on the notion that rates are skyrocketing. If that narrative is false, some argue, such coverage risks baselessly frightening people who are considering having kids. 

In this case, the critics are right, to a point. Most experts agree with Dattaniâ€™s conclusion. The CDCâ€™s research â€œshows that observed increases in nationwide maternal mortality rates between 2003 and 2017 were largely due to the implementation of the checkbox, which increased identification of maternal deaths,â€ a spokesperson told Vox in a statement. The CDC has been open about that fact since at least 2020, but the issue of the checkbox received little public attention until now.

However, the number of maternal deaths also continued to rise after 2017, when all states had adopted the checkbox. Some of the rise after 2020, Dattani and others say, may be due to Covid, which was especially dangerous for pregnant people, particularly before the arrival of vaccines.Â 

The bottom line is that the pregnancy checkbox probably explains a lot of the increase in reported maternal mortality over the past several decades, but not all of it. Meanwhile, thereâ€™s another big point of contention around the checkbox and its impact.

Other researchers say the CDC overcounts maternal deaths

The addition of the pregnancy checkbox has led the CDC to classify deaths as related to pregnancy when they really arenâ€™t, contends a research team led by K.S. Joseph, a professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of British Columbia. For example, pregnant women who die of cancer can be classified as cases of maternal mortality, the researchers argued in a paper published in March in the American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology.Â 

Using a more conservative methodology, the researchers calculated a maternal mortality rate of 10.4 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2018-2021, compared to the 23.6 per 100,000 reported by the CDC for that timeframe.

Critics of the CDC numbers are not advocating for pulling resources away from maternal health initiatives. Womenâ€™s reproductive health in general remains underfunded, and money set aside to combat maternal mortality is often a drop in the bucket of state and federal budgets.Â 

Still, some scholars and advocates are concerned that criticism of the CDCâ€™s count could lead to maternal health work being deprioritized. â€œIt would be an unfortunate setback to see all the hard work of health care professionals, policy makers, patient advocates, and other stakeholders be undermined by this publication,â€ Christopher Zahn, interim CEO of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, wrote in response to the research by Joseph and his team.

The CDC also strongly disputes that research, arguing that the methodology used by Joseph and his team would significantly undercount maternal deaths. A pregnant woman who dies of cancer is actually an example of maternal mortality if she has to pause her chemotherapy during pregnancy and her cancer advances as a result, the CDC spokesperson told Vox. 

Without the checkbox system, the spokesperson said, many deaths would simply be missed: â€œCapturing these otherwise unrecorded maternal deaths is critical to understanding the scope of maternal mortality in the United States and taking effective public health action to prevent these deaths.â€ 

Others also agree that capturing deaths from underlying conditions that may be worsened by pregnancy is crucial for public health. â€œWe know that poor health entering into pregnancy can lead to mortality postpartum in the â€˜fourth trimester,â€™â€ Louise King, a professor of obstetrics, gynecology, and reproductive biology at Harvard University, told Vox in an email. â€œShouldn’t we want to classify the death of a pregnant person with hypertension as a maternal death? So that we can address what might be the underlying cause of this â€” lack of preventative health care, lack of appropriate postpartum care given current insurance coverage in [the] US?â€

And many scholars, including Dattani, agree that the introduction of the checkbox has led to better data, not worse. â€œMy view is not that this is overestimating,â€ she told Vox. â€œIn fact, it’s identifying maternal deaths that had been missed in the past.â€

So, is there a maternal mortality crisis in the US?

Even if the CDC data isnâ€™t perfect, many scholars agree that far too many people are dying during and after childbirth in the United States.

We have many sources of information about maternal mortality, said Laurie Zephyrin, a senior vice president for advancing health equity at the Commonwealth Fund. The CDCâ€™s National Center for Health Statistics releases the numbers that have been most debated recently, but the agency also has a Pregnancy Mortality Surveillance System that employs medical epidemiologists to comb through death records from pregnancy up to a year after birth. Meanwhile, state and local maternal mortality review committees also independently investigate maternal deaths. â€œAll three of these ways of collecting data are showing that we have a problem in this country,â€ Zephyrin said.

We can also understand US maternal health better by putting it an international context. Comparing maternal mortality across countries can be complex, for some of the same reasons itâ€™s complicated to count maternal deaths within the US. Some countries use a pregnancy checkbox like the one added in the US while others do not, leading to concerns that other nations may be underreporting maternal deaths, making the US look worse by comparison.

However, we know that the US lags behind other countries when it comes to policies proven to improve maternal (and overall) health. Among wealthy countries, the US is the only one without universal health care, said Munira Gunja, a senior researcher with the Commonwealth Fundâ€™s International Program in Health Policy and Practice Innovations. It’s also the only one without federally mandated paid parental leave, and it’s the only country that doesnâ€™t provide home visits and other comprehensive postpartum care, instead often limiting birthing people to a lone doctorâ€™s appointment six weeks after birth. â€œThe US is a clear outlier, particularly when it comes to postpartum support,â€ Gunja said.

Meanwhile, everyone involved in the debate over counting maternal deaths agrees that Black birthing people are dying at a disproportionately high rate. That disparity shows up whether you use the CDCâ€™s method or Josephâ€™s, and itâ€™s indicative of bigger problems within the US health care system, experts say. Black Americans in general have a lower life expectancy than white Americans, and Black babies are more likely to be stillborn or die in infancy. â€œThis is across the board, not just in maternal health,â€ said Angela D. Aina, co-founder and executive director of the Black Mamas Matter Alliance.

Some have argued that the language of â€œcrisisâ€ is unproductive, frightening pregnant people and prospective parents and clouding the search for solutions. â€œThe constant drumbeat that maternal mortality is â€˜commonplaceâ€™ and that pregnancy is â€˜deadlyâ€™ doesnâ€™t empower me with information to make my own decisions,â€ Jerusalem Demsas writes at the Atlantic. â€œIt just stresses me out.â€

Reasonable people can disagree over what constitutes a crisis and over the best way to measure how often Americans experience the tragic situation in which a person who is already sick dies from their illness after giving birth.Â 

But experts do not disagree on the basic premise that too many pregnant and birthing people are dying in America, that many of their deaths are preventable, and that we already know some of the reforms â€” from paid leave to better prenatal and postpartum care â€” that would save their lives.

entry.content:
In 1955, the philosopher Charles Frankel was troubled. A committed civil libertarian, he had come to believe that the prevailing winds of public life had turned against his beloved liberalism. He wrote a book, The Case for Modern Man, defending it from critics on the left and right alike.

His concluding chapter, titled â€œThe Revolution of Modernity,â€ argued that liberalism had succeeded on a more fundamental level than most appreciated. Liberal modernity has not only been the era of technological progress and rapid economic growth, but also â€œa moral revolution of extraordinary scope, a radical alteration in what the human imagination is prepared to envisage and demand.â€

One contemporary reviewer urged Frankel to expand on these concluding remarks at book length â€” to explain how this moral revolution worked and how it would shape our world. But Frankel never did. In fairness, he was quite busy: He left his post at Columbia University to join the State Department, only to quit in 1967 in protest of the Vietnam War. He spent the rest of his shortened life advocating for civil liberties and the humanities, murdered in 1979 during a robbery at his New York home.

Frankel lived just long enough to see his optimism vindicated by events. The rise of the civil rights movement, feminism, and LGBT activism proved that liberalism had indeed altered the kinds of moral equality that Americans were prepared to demand. Liberalismâ€™s central idea, that society should allow all people to live their lives as free and equal citizens, had never come closer to reality in all of human history.

Our moment, like Frankelâ€™s, is a seemingly dire time for liberalism: a moment where it faces an extinction-level threat from the rise of authoritarian movements inside its historical bastions. Intellectuals are once again predicting liberalismâ€™s imminent doom. Is there any hope that they are as wrong as the obituaries penned during Frankelâ€™s time?

The answer, I believe is yes. To understand why, we should turn to a new book that finally delivers on the promise of Frankelâ€™s concluding chapter â€” and, in the process, helps us understand what a future liberal revival might look.

Our liberal soul

Liberalism as a Way of Life, by Canadian political theorist Alexandre Lefebvre, is an unusual work of philosophy â€” pairing exposition of John Rawlsâ€™ theory of moral psychology with analyses of The Good Place and headlines in The Onion.Â 

The goal is to illustrate something Lefebvre believes has been lost: the idea that liberalism is not merely a political philosophy, but rather a set of implicitly shared values and norms that define social life in advanced democratic societies.

â€œWritten into our foundational institutions, and underlying so much of the culture we daily live and breathe, liberalism has seeped into our pores so as to profoundly and personally shape who we are,â€ Lefebvre writes.

Think about what you believe about the world, on a really elementary level. Does it start with the idea that all people deserve to be treated equally? That no one person is fundamentally better than any other? That each person should be free to live life in the way that they want, and still be treated with kindness and respect?

These, Lefebvre argues, are liberal beliefs â€” ones that have spread only recently and to only some parts of the world. But in those parts, these liberal values are so widely and commonly accepted that most people consider them nothing more than common sense. We are liberals and we donâ€™t even know it.

One of Lefebvreâ€™s most vivid illustrations is his discussion of English-language swear words.

It used to be that the worst curses focused on hygiene, religion, and sexual morality. But words like â€œshit,â€ â€œfuck,â€ and â€œdamnâ€ have lost their sting, now considered more impolite than offensive. We print them in Vox without much pushback from either readers or editors.

The words that actually cause offense nowadays are slurs â€” especially ones that target minorities and marginalized groups. These are the words that truly shock people today, language that could blow up a dinner party or give cause for a hostile workplace lawsuit. I canâ€™t imagine a circumstance in which I would publish an article with uncensored versions of them.

For Lefebvre, this shift in linguistic norms reflects a deeper moral regime change.

Swear words derive their power from transgression, a kind of verbal shorthand that communicates disregard for prevailing social norms. The classic four-letter words transgressed against Victorian ideals of sexual morality and purity; their declining power represents the declining hold of those ideas on our collective morality. Slurs have taken their place because they transgress against liberalism â€” specifically, the liberal idea that all humans deserve equal respect regardless of their identity.

â€œA slur is a missile aimed at self-respect. It diminishes a personâ€™s value, dismisses their goals, and undermines their confidence,â€ he writes. â€œIf you condemn slurs no matter who they are aimed at â€¦ and if you are provoked by them in a way no other word has the power to do, then you are liberal in at least this respect.â€

The slurs example, and many others, illustrate how liberalism has become more than a political doctrine about rights and democracy: It is, in liberal countries, the invisible source of many of our most basic ways of living. Liberal ideas shape the way we think about everything from government to religion to sports to friendship.Â 

It is, as Lefebvre writes, â€œthe water in which we swim:â€ as omnipresent and taken-for-granted as the ocean is for its fish.

Liberalism versus â€œliberaldomâ€

Lefebvreâ€™s analysis raises an obvious question. If liberal ideas about equality and freedom are so dominant in places like the United States, how come our country is so unequal and unfree?

To explain the gap, Lefebvre borrows a concept from the 19th-century Christian philosopher SÃ¸ren Kierkegaard. For Kierkegaard, true Christianity was a radical moral doctrine that preached total devotion to others and the renunciation of worldly pleasures. This was, of course, at odds with the way nominally Christian societies â€” including their churches â€” operated at the time. 

Thus, Kierkegaard distinguished between Christianity, on the one hand, and â€œChristendomâ€ on the other. In Christendom, church leaders said the right things and performed the right rituals, but flagrantly violated Christian ethics in their actual lives. In Christendom, Kierkegaard wrote, the pastor is â€œa royal office holder, advancing steadily, making a careerâ€”and now he dramatically plays at Christianity, in short, he is performing comedy.â€

Today, Lefebvre argues, we are living in liberaldom â€” a liberalism as compromised, infected and diluted by other forces as Christianity was in Kierkegaardâ€™s time. â€œLiberaldom, we could say, is the craven capitulation to unliberal values that threaten to destroy your and my spirit,â€ he writes.

Lefebvre doesnâ€™t offer a macro-solution to the problem of liberaldom. His task isnâ€™t to theorize about politics traditionally conceived, like mass movements and elections. Instead, he aspires to write something like self-help: instructing liberals on how they can live a good life even when faced with the reality of liberaldom, detailing a list of â€œspiritual exercisesâ€ that can help us be more authentic liberals.

â€œLiberaldom is not something â€˜out thereâ€™ in the world but rather anchored in a pattern of wants, aspirations, and habits built up over a lifetime. Unlearning it takes work and effort,â€ he writes. 

Itâ€™s a novel idea (most of Lefebvreâ€™s ideas are). But it also can feel a bit unsatisfying at a moment of liberal crisis. The New Yorkerâ€™s Adam Gopnik, for example, writes that Lefebvreâ€™s idea of spiritual exercise â€œseems scarcely more likely to get us through 2024 than smoking weed all day.â€

Surely thatâ€™s an unfair standard. But itâ€™s also a misunderstanding of Lefebvreâ€™s project. His aim is not merely to help liberals be happier or calmer, but to rescue them from liberaldom. His goal is for readers to think through where their values and lives conflict, and figure out how to bring them in line. It is to create ways for people to confront the contradictions inherent to their lives and, ultimately, to resolve them in favor of their values.

Toppling liberaldom

The clearest pathway forward can be found in Lefebvreâ€™s treatment of â€œreflective equilibrium,â€ a tool of moral reasoning developed by Lefebvreâ€™s intellectual hero (and mine): John Rawls. The greatest liberal philosopher of the 20th century, Rawls is best known for his book A Theory of Justice â€” which almost single-handedly revived political philosophy in the Anglophone world.

â€œReflective equilibriumâ€ is one of Rawlsâ€™ less well-known concepts (at least outside of academic philosophy). It is a deliberate process where people start with a basic thing they believe to be true, draw out its implications, and see whether there are any contradictions that must be resolved. You repeat this process until youâ€™re satisfied that everything is consistent â€” in equilibrium, so to speak.

Take an example: thinking through the morality of killing.

If you start from the premise that killing is always wrong, youâ€™re quickly led to the conclusion that killing in self-defense is also wrong. But most people donâ€™t think that it seems like if someone is trying to murder you, you should be able to fight back. Therefore, upon reflection, you should probably modify the original principle: instead of saying that killing is always wrong, you probably want to say that killing is almost always wrong. You keep testing and probing, figuring out what conditions should count as exceptions to the â€œno killingâ€ rule. When you think youâ€™re done, and that all your beliefs about killing are consistent, youâ€™ve arrived at reflective equilibrium.

For Lefebvre, reflective equilibrium can be a means of testing whether our lives actually live up to our liberal values â€” and for refining our beliefs, and even everyday practices, to better fit with what we profess. 

â€œThe person who achieves such an equilibrium will be less susceptible to hypocrisy,â€ he says. â€œThey will have brought their ideas, feelings, principles, and desires into alignment. Fluency and candor, grace and self-command, will be theirs.â€

If he is right â€” and I believe he is â€” then the implications are not merely individual. If human beings are creatures who can reflect on our ideas and, when confronted with contradiction, believe that we need to change, then that creates a potential pathway for broader social change. Even in liberaldom, many people genuinely believe in liberal ideas; they get angry when theyâ€™re flouted by the state and its agents. Under such circumstances, identifying a gap between liberal belief and liberaldomâ€™s reality can be a potentially radical act.

In the United States, this is the history of successful movements for social change. In his famous address â€œWhat to the Slave is the Fourth of July,â€ abolitionist Frederick Douglass made the contradictions between the liberalism of Americaâ€™s founding and the liberaldom of the slaveholding South a central theme. 

â€œWould you have me argue that man is entitled to liberty? That he is the rightful owner of his own body? You have already declared it,â€ Douglass said. â€œFor revolting barbarity and shameless hypocrisy, America reigns without a rival.â€

But â€œnotwithstanding the dark picture I have this day presented, I do not despair of this country,â€ he added. â€œThere are forces in operation, which must inevitably work the downfall of slavery.â€ No modern society, in Douglassâ€™ view, could long survive the ruinous tension between slavery and freedom. Eventually, something had to give â€” and Douglass was convinced that, given the â€œobvious tendencies of the age,â€ liberalism would win out over liberaldom.

Ultimately, he was right: The rising popularity of the abolitionist cause led to Abraham Lincolnâ€™s election. While the motivating power of Americaâ€™s liberal ideas was hardly the only reason for slaveryâ€™s doom, it was a vital one.

This holds true in the grand contest for liberalism today. In my own forthcoming book, The Reactionary Spirit, I argue that elected authoritarians â€” like Donald Trump and Viktor OrbÃ¡n â€” are vulnerable precisely because they claim to stand for democracy. 

The contradiction between their stated beliefs and actions creates fertile ground for their opponents to appeal to the pro-democracy consensus in their societies. And indeed, there is substantial evidence from recent elections in the United States, Brazil, Poland, and India that this can be a winning tactic.

But this tactic is not merely useful in defending liberalism from its enemies. It has also proven effective in improving our liberal societies: enacting reforms that bring them closer to their stated ideals. 

Take, for example, the pro-housing YIMBY movement. The very name, Yes in My Backyard, is a play on the older term NIMBYÂ  â€” referring to the kind of faux-liberals who like the idea of wind power or affordable housing but wonâ€™t support such projects if they affect local property values. YIMBYs argue that, if you take the beliefs of liberal urban dwellers seriously, you must support building more and building faster to deal with Americaâ€™s catastrophic housing crisis.

And guess what? Itâ€™s working! 

â€œI used to keep track of individual YIMBY policy wins, but at a certain point I stopped because there were just too many,â€ Matt Yglesias writes at Slow Boring. â€œI have met actual human beings living in Arlington who read Richard Rothsteinâ€™s â€˜The Color of Law,â€™ found that it genuinely changed their mind, and now are eager to fight the legacy of white supremacy by opening the door to expanding housing supply.â€

Back in 1955, Charles Frankel called on his comrades to â€œreconstruct the liberal tradition to make it applicable to an age of technical specialization, bureaucratized power, and mass movements.â€ Today, liberals like the YIMBYs are doing just that by acting on the insights embedded in Lefebvreâ€™s book. Their successes should give us hope that contemporary liberaldom is no more inevitable than the liberaldoms of 1854 or 1954Â â€”Â and that liberalismâ€™s reigning status as dominant moral doctrine provides resources to beat back illiberal challenges.

entry.title: Delete your dating apps and find romance offline
entry.summary: Ali Jackson had been single for about four years, and like so many women, felt burned out on dating apps.
